awd_titl_txt: FET: Small: A closed-loop electronically automated platform for debugging synthetic biology
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to increase the scalability of synthetic-biology debugging systems that could have broad applications in extending capabilities for cell-based sensors and actuators in medicine and agriculture, as well as for addition to new knowledge generation in molecular-biology research. This will be accomplished by building an end-to-end biomolecular-silicon hybrid system. Broadly, the resulting system will: (1) explore new ways to build hybrid bio-molecular silicon computer systems by integrating bio-molecular storage and computing with electronics, and (2) automate closed-loop synthetic biology design-build-test-learn processes. Importantly, this project will also train students and professionals in the intersection of biology and computing, which is a very promising new area of scientific and economic development. Results from this work will also be incorporated into new course materials at the intersection of embedded computing/fluidics, molecular biology and machine learning, with the goal of training students to quickly prototype ideas in molecular computing/synthetic biology.

The investigators will design and build scalable bio-molecular computing and debugging tools on top of a closed-loop system that integrates a nanopore sensor array for biomolecule-to-digital read-out (DNA and protein) with a DNA synthesizer for digital-to-biomolecule interface, automated with a digital/droplet microfluidic system and an integrated programming model (PurpleDrop+Puddle). The digital fluidics system will employ computer-vision techniques for reliable control of droplet movements. The investigators will develop machine-learning techniques to analyze raw nanopore sensor data for low-cost and high-throughput identification of molecular outputs. Specifically, the system will achieve two main objectives. The first objective will combine DNA synthesis and digital microfluidics for assembly of biological parts to implement automated cloning, in-line with DNA sequencing-based quality control. The second objective is transcriptional circuit auto-tuning, which will carry out automated characterization and parallel component debugging/tuning of designed in-vivo transcriptional circuits using a library of new genetic reporter proteins. For each objective, the nanopore sensor array will read-out the molecular results (DNA or protein); the control system (Puddle) will then interpret the data and determine the next fluidic manipulation actions as well as the production of additional synthetic DNA to guide the design or discovery process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to explore the integration of bio-molecular computing with digital microfluidics. The outcomes of this project have shown promising developments in several areas, contributing both to scientific knowledge and practical applications at the intersection of biotechnology and computing.


Intellectual Merit

A key achievement was the development and application of nanopore-addressable reporters for reading outputs from biomolecular circuitry, including cell, protein and DNA-based systems. These tools help in monitoring molecular processes in synthetic biomolecular systems, providing new levels of multiplexing outputs and kinetic characteristics. Another significant contribution was addressing the issue of droplet evaporation in digital microfluidic (DMF) devices, which is particularly problematic during PCR processes. By designing an off-board heated PDMS chamber, the project offered a practical solution that improves the efficiency and reliability of these processes. In software development, the project also developed machine learning techniques to interpret complex nanopore signal data. This advancement is a step forward in nanopore signal analysis, allowing for more detailed and automated analysis of nanopore datasets. Overall, the project also experimented with merging bio-molecular components with electronic systems. This exploration paves the way for further possibilities in bio-molecular computing, potentially leading to innovative hybrid systems that combine biological and electronic elements.


Broader Impacts

Beyond the molecular computing community, the project's outcomes have implications in various fields. In education, the techniques and tools developed could be used to enhance teaching methods in bioengineering and synthetic biology, making these advanced topics more accessible to students. The advancements in biomolecule detection could be applied in environmental science for monitoring pollutants and pathogens, contributing to environmental conservation efforts and public health. In the medical field, the improved PCR techniques and applications of NanoporeTERs offer potential enhancements in diagnostic methods and drug development. These could lead to more efficient medical treatments and personalized medicine approaches. Additionally, the project's work in data analysis can be relevant to other areas that handle complex datasets, providing new methods that could be adapted to different contexts.


Throughout the duration of the grant, this project has made meaningful impacts in molecular automation, biosensing, and molecular computing. Its intellectual contributions lie in the development of new tools and methods for biomolecular computing and microfluidics. The broader impacts of the project are evident in its potential applications in education, environmental science, medicine, and beyond. The outcomes reflect the project's role in bridging computing and biomolecules for both scientific exploration and practical application, highlighting the value of this interdisciplinary research area.


Last Modified: 01/04/2024
Modified by: Luis Ceze
